An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.

Does the concept of a/an Factorial ring/unique factorization domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Greatest common divisor to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Greatest Common Divisor (GCD) does not inherently require the structure of a Factorial Ring or Unique Factorization Domain (UFD) to be defined. The definition of a GCD only requires the ability to determine divisibility within a ring, specifically that one element divides another. This is a property that can be defined in any integral domain or even more generally in any ring.

A Factorial Ring or UFD, by its definition, provides additional structure by ensuring that every non-zero non-unit element can be uniquely factored into irreducibles (which are also primes). This property is helpful for many purposes, including simplifying the computation of GCDs, but it is not a prerequisite for the concept of GCD itself. The existence and calculation of a GCD do not depend on the unique factorization property but rather on the divisibility relations within the ring.

Therefore, while the structure of a UFD can make working with GCDs more straightforward and can guarantee the existence of GCDs in more cases, it is not necessary for the definition or existence of GCDs in a general sense. GCDs can be defined and exist in rings that are not UFDs, such as in certain non-UFD integral domains where unique factorization does not hold.
